Note how λ FP < 1 drives the total factory production capacity to be smaller than the total demand, indicating a situation in which there is less reagent than the nation needs. Values of λ FP ≥ 1 drive the total reagent production towards meeting the demand; in this case, tests not performed because of lack of reagent are more likely due to poor resource allocation over the national territory, rather than an absolute scarcity of reagent. This second pattern simulates a situation in which it is infeasible, due to logistic constraints, to have daily shipments out of the factories. Fig. 8b shows an example of bumpy production. The coloured bars correspond to the quantities released by the factories on their release days, while grey background bars count the total amount of reagent released on that day, by all factories.
